Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Structural Health Monitoring and Damage Detection for Highly Variable Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Structural health monitoring aims to detect damage and assess critical, physical infrastructures over long periods of time. The infrastructures assessed can include pipelines, bridges, steel cables, aircrafts, trains, and power plants. Due to the significant complexity and variability of structural health monitoring data, current technology can only reasonably assess limited amounts of information. Yet, as structural health monitoring expands to more complex problems and its data includes hundreds of terabytes of structural data over several decades, big data strategies become essential. This award supports fundamental research to integrate statistical, big data strategies with structural health monitoring systems. The new, integrated framework will enable the tracking and the anticipation of structural damage in harsh, highly variable environments over many years. This study will provide tools for the detection of structural damage before catastrophic failures occur. Results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society by improving safety and reducing life-cycle costs of many civil and mechanical systems, from airplanes to bridges to pipelines. The research also promotes highly interdisciplinary collaboration as the research employs methods and solves problems found across the disciplines of electrical and computer engineering, computer science, mechanical engineering, and civil engineering. This diverse subject matter will promote a multidisciplinary engineering education and help to recruit and broaden the participation of underrepresented students in research.

This project will statistically identify barely visible, critically important trends in large (gigabyte to terabyte size) structural health monitoring data sets. Three primary challenges are addressed: (1) distorting environmental conditions, (2) poor scaling to large data sets, and (3) no standard statistic for reliability. This project addresses these three challenges through the creation of a modular big data structural health monitoring framework based on dynamic time warping, singular value decomposition, factor analysis, and maximum likelihood statistics. The big data structural health monitoring framework is assessed through several short-term (hours to days) and long-term (multi-year) structural health monitoring experiments that introduce composite panels to a variety of damage and environmental conditions. These experiments provide statistical validation as well as a unique opportunity to study the effects of environmental parameters on composite structural health monitoring data.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:

Health monitoring systems for structures, materials, and manufacturing have the amazing potential to ensure the health and safety of the world?s aging infrastructure over long periods. Yet, tracking material and structural variations (e.g., crack growth, corrosion, or other forms of degradation) are exceedingly difficult. This is because (1) data is heavily altered by small, environmental conditions (such as temperature, loading, moisture, etc.), (2) there exists limited frameworks for scaling current research methods to large-scale data sets, and (3) there exists few standard statistical measures for assessing the reliability of current systems.

As a result, this project studied the creation of algorithms to identify barely visible, critically important trends in large data sets. Our successes include

(1) a structural health monitoring framework for storing and processing large ultrasonic datasets consisting of multiple terabytes of data,

(2) new strategies for reducing effects of the environment (that can ruin damage detection and localization) for much broader environmental conditions (e.g., greater temperature distributions) and broader signal properties (e.g., higher frequencies) than previously possible,

(3) techniques for statistical detection and localization of structural damage that no longer require prior knowledge or assumptions about the expected data,

(4) a framework for statistical models of ultrasonic guided waves that can be used to evaluate the performance of damage detection methodologies,

(5) preliminary machine learning algorithms that can parse large, multi-terabyte ultrasonic structural health monitoring datasets for identifying important events, such as damage or other strong data variations.

We also created a unique experiment system and been collecting a unique ultrasonic structural health monitoring dataset from an outdoor health monitoring system for the last two to three years (consisting of more than 3 Terabytes (TB) of data). This dataset offers insight into how common environmental factors affecting ultrasonic structural health monitoring data.


Intellectual Merit:

Many ultrasonic structural health monitoring strategies often only analyze a few measurements from a short period, and the damage is often detected by comparing only two measurements at a time: a baseline and the current measurement. Yet, as we expand structural health monitoring to more complex problems, big data strategies are becoming essential. Sensors will eventually record hundreds of terabytes of data, and we will need to utilize all of this information with a robust statistical method to achieve reliable damage detection results. This project has provided a road map for overcoming these challenges.

Broader Impacts: 

The detection of structural damage in harsh, highly variable environments through our improvement data analytics will help reduce catastrophic failures, improve safety, and reduce the life-cycle costs of many civil and mechanical systems, from airplanes to bridges to pipes. Also, this project has been an effort at the intersection of electrical and computer engineering, computer science, and mechanical engineering. As a result, it has been an excellent vehicle for educational outreach. The project has been used to mentor undergraduate researchers through various programs during fall, spring, and summer semesters. Graduate students mentoring these undergraduates have grown as researchers and leaderships as a result of these experiences. Portions of this project were also used to help instruct K-12 teachers on the importance of data analytics and how they related to real-world challenges.


Last Modified: 08/30/2020
Modified by: Daniel O Adams

Images (1 of )
  • Summary illustration of our successes and combined framework.
    Daniel O. Adams and Joel B. Harley
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Daniel O Adams
    Summary Figure
  • Run times of singular value decomposition with different compression ratios. This shows that we can use big data compression methods to reduce our data size to less than 1% of the original to achieve large speed improvements. This comes with almost no degradation in damage detection performance.
    Sungwon Kim, Spencer Shiveley, Alexander C. S. Douglass, Yisong Zhang, Rajeev Sahay, Daniel O. Adams, and Joel B. Harley, "Efficient Storage and Processing of Large Guided Wave Data Sets with Random Projection," Structural Health Monitoring, under review.
    Copyrighted
    Daniel O Adams
    Large ultrasonic data framework
  • Correlations and stretch factors from the scale transform, dynamic time warping, and no compensation for 200kHz center frequency ultrasonic data. This demonstrates that our new approach (dynamic time warping) provides greater resilience when compared with the scale transform (state-of-the-art).
    A. C. S. Douglass and J. B. Harley, �Dynamic Time Warping Temperature Compensation for Guided Wave Structural Health Monitoring,� IEEE Trans. Ultrason. Ferroelectr. Freq. Control, vol. 65, no. 5, pp. 851�861, May 2018.
    Copyrighted
    Daniel O Adams
    Reducing environmental effects
  • Localization results when (a) when damage is absent and (b) when damage is present. (c) Same plot as (b), but magnified around the damage location. (d) to (f) Same plots as (a) to (c), respectively, but values below our statistical threshold. White squares represent M=100 measurements.
    J. B. Harley and C. C. Chia, �Statistical partial wavefield imaging using Lamb wave signals,� Structural Health Monitoring, vol. 17, no. 4, pp. 919�935, Jul. 2018.
    Daniel O Adams
    New Statistical Techniques
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Summary: Health monitoring systems for structures, materials, and manufacturing have the amazing potential to ensure the health and safety of the world?s aging infrastructure over long periods. Yet, tracking material and structural variations (e.g., crack growth, corrosion, or other forms of degradation) are exceedingly difficult. This is because (1) data is heavily altered by small, environmental conditions (such as temperature, loading, moisture, etc.), (2) there exists limited frameworks for scaling current research methods to large-scale data sets, and (3) there exists few standard statistical measures for assessing the reliability of current systems. As a result, this project studied the creation of algorithms to identify barely visible, critically important trends in large data sets. Our successes include (1) a structural health monitoring framework for storing and processing large ultrasonic datasets consisting of multiple terabytes of data, (2) new strategies for reducing effects of the environment (that can ruin damage detection and localization) for much broader environmental conditions (e.g., greater temperature distributions) and broader signal properties (e.g., higher frequencies) than previously possible, (3) techniques for statistical detection and localization of structural damage that no longer require prior knowledge or assumptions about the expected data, (4) a framework for statistical models of ultrasonic guided waves that can be used to evaluate the performance of damage detection methodologies, (5) preliminary machine learning algorithms that can parse large, multi-terabyte ultrasonic structural health monitoring datasets for identifying important events, such as damage or other strong data variations. We also created a unique experiment system and been collecting a unique ultrasonic structural health monitoring dataset from an outdoor health monitoring system for the last two to three years (consisting of more than 3 Terabytes (TB) of data). This dataset offers insight into how common environmental factors affecting ultrasonic structural health monitoring data. Yet, as we expand structural health monitoring to more complex problems, big data strategies are becoming essential. Sensors will eventually record hundreds of terabytes of data, and we will need to utilize all of this information with a robust statistical method to achieve reliable damage detection results. This project has provided a road map for overcoming these challenges. Broader Impacts: The detection of structural damage in harsh, highly variable environments through our improvement data analytics will help reduce catastrophic failures, improve safety, and reduce the life-cycle costs of many civil and mechanical systems, from airplanes to bridges to pipes. Also, this project has been an effort at the intersection of electrical and computer engineering, computer science, and mechanical engineering. As a result, it has been an excellent vehicle for educational outreach. The project has been used to mentor undergraduate researchers through various programs during fall, spring, and summer semesters. Graduate students mentoring these undergraduates have grown as researchers and leaderships as a result of these experiences.
